intro: Lesquerella rosulata, commonly known as the rose-leaved lesquerella, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes mustard and cabbage plants. The plant is characterized by its rosette-forming leaves and small, yellow flowers that bloom in late spring. Lesquerella rosulata is known for producing oils that have industrial applications, particularly in the production of lubricants and coatings. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often found in rocky soils and along canyon walls.
